subject: RE: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... True. What would someone motivate to do so? ... Agreed. And I think the same is true when someone provides his own implementation of an interface. He had
messageBody:
> None of which prevents somebody from writing their own implementation
> of the interface, instantiating it and bypassing the factories
> completely.

True. What would someone motivate to do so?

> The source (or byte) code can always be forked. At that point it's out
> of my hands, and not really my responsibility.

Agreed. And I think the same is true when someone provides his own
implementation of an interface. He had to do so deliberately, so it's his
responsibility to make it work.


> But they can't just
> swap out my class for a different one, if I've written the
> implementation to depend on classes rather than interfaces. That's
> pretty much the point.

Exactly. And to me that's a *disadvantage*, because it makes the system less
flexible and reusable.


>> Thirdly, interfaces define contracts. Implementations which do not
>> conform to the contracts aren't socially responsible - you shouldn't
>> build them that way. How do you make sure you build them right?
>> Testing, peer reviews, and well-defined types.
>
> All good ideas, but if this were sufficient we never would have needed
> access protection in the first place.

What makes you think we *needed* it?


> However one
> thing they all have in common is that they're using my code because
> they implicitly or explicitly trust me and my library(s). I promise
> that the library behaves in a certain way under certain conditions and
> accomplishes certain tasks. I can do this only because my libraries
> are designed around concrete classes.

I don't think the last sentence is true. For example "under certain
conditions" could include "for implementations that conform to the contracts
as defined in the interface's javadocs."

> If someone replaces the BAR
> class with a misbehaving version, then not just BAR but also FOO and
> everything else that depends on it could be compromised.

Again, I think of this as a feature: by replacing the Bar class with a
version behaving differently, I can customize the behaviour of the whole
system.

Just think about the Comparator interface. Of course I can implement a
Comparator that doesn't conform to the Comparator contract (for example one
that isn't symmetric), but that is *my* responsibility, not Sun's. (Sun's
responsibility is to communicate the contract, of course.)

My 0.02...

Cheers, Ilja
